Award.AwardTitle: CRCNS: BrainPack: A Suite of Advanced Statistical Techniques for Mmulti-Subject, Multi-Group Neuroimaging Data Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the neural bases of psychiatric disorders is a critical component in the development of targeted behavioral or drug therapies. Given the rapid advancements in availability of, and access to brain imaging equipment, there now exists a large literature reporting on functional neuroimaging results differentiating people with psychotic disorders (such as schizophrenia) from healthy people. The literature is littered, however, with failures to replicate. The popularity of imaging as a research tool in psychiatric disorders, and the lack of consistency in results, provide a compelling demonstration of why resources would be well invested on the development of more reliable, accurate and sensitive tools for analyzing data. These tools must be based on sound statistical theory, yet accommodate the actual, practical challenges caused by the realities of the data. The project develops a suite of robust, sensitive and effective statistical methods which will help neuroscientists better understand the etiology of psychiatric disorders. The enhanced sensitivity of these tools also creates a better means for evaluating new treatments, as it provides improved assessment of changes across time that are currently difficult to capture due to their subtle nature.

The suite of methods developed in the project (BrainPack) is a comprehensive system for the analysis of group-level imaging data that makes minimal assumptions on the distributional behavior of the measured signal. It does not require an a priori model of the expected activation across sessions, can effectively reduce the size of large data sets containing mostly irrelevant information, account for spatial and temporal correlations, and quantify the discrepancy between groups and assess the statistical significance of these discrepancies. As such BrainPack will provide robust identification of subtle group differences that are common across many types of neuroimaging studies. These advancements are generalizable and readily adapted across a wide range of neuroimaging studies and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Brain structure and function can be assessed using MRI. Specifically, brain function is evaluated using fMRI. This widely used technique has provided insights across varied fields including psychology, neurology, biology, kinesiology, and psychiatry.  Recently, however, inferences generated using fMRI data have come under fire primarily due to a high profile manuscripts that suggested that studies using fMRI data are either not replicable or provide false positives.  Some of these problems are intertwined with the nature of the data.  FMRI data are large, often not normally distributed or independent and with an inherently low signal to noise ratio. These critiques reinforce the need to develop excellent analysis tools. In this project, we developed a powerful set of statistical tools, called the BrainPack Suite, to solve persistent problems in fMRI data analysis. The BrainPack Suite is rooted in statistical theory and the resulting fMRI analysis is sensitive and more reliable.  The Suite of methods developed in the project is a comprehensive system for the analysis of group-level imaging data that makes minimal assumptions on the distributional behavior of the measured signal. It does not require an a priori model of the expected activation across sessions, and can effectively reduce the size of large data sets containing mostly irrelevant information. Also, it accounts for spatial and temporal correlations, and quantifies the discrepancy between groups and assess the statistical significance of these discrepancies. As such BrainPack provides robust identification of subtle group differences that are common across many types of neuroimaging studies. These advancements are generalizable and readily adapted across a wide range of neuroimaging studies and beyond.

The results from this project are likely to make an impact on real world issues because the BrainPack Suite advances what we know about brain function, an issue that lies at the root of all behavior, both disordered and healthy. Understanding disordered brain function provides insight for clinical disorders. Given high rates of psychiatric and neurological disorders in the world population, brain-based diseases have high societal costs.  Alternatively, understanding healthy brain function may lead to practical identification of pro-brain practices that could be used to optimize brain health over the course of life.  Being able to support better brain health would have numerous positive health consequences and a corresponding decrease in fiscal resources needed to manage disease and aging. 

To accomplish the goals of developing new statistical approaches to be applied to fMRI data, the entire team met weekly for data presentations on analysis strategies applied to several fMRI data sets. The team is a part of the UGA neuroimaging data analysis group. In total, the group consists of 5 faculty members (3 Professors, 1 Associate Professor, and 1 Assistant Professor) from the Statistics and Psychology departments and have advised 19 PhD students, 7 MS students, and 2 undergraduate students across departments during the award period.  The students received mentorship in MRI basics, data analysis, data presentation (both written and spoken) and in critical evaluation of academic work. During weekly presentations, suggestions and improvements were generated among the attendees that were considered and executed during the week and then integrated into the next week’s presentation. Additional progress was facilitated by frequent drop in meetings between the PIs and students which occurred daily, or multiple times a day.  The team also hosted the 6th NOGGINS (Network of Greater Georgia Institutions for Neuroimaging and Statistics) workshop on April 13, 2018 at UGA with 28 participants. The workshop provides a forum for scientific communication and collaboration between researchers in the area of neuroscience and neuroimaging. We invited the keynote speaker (Dr. Timothy Johnson, University of Michigan). Other presenters included faculty from UGA Computer Science and Emory Biostatistics, as well as 2 graduate students from Statistics and 3 from Psychology.  The National Institute of Statistical Science co-sponsored the event. The team organized the 7th NOGGINS workshop on March 27, 2020, but it was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Regarding dissemination, four papers have been published, three papers have been submitted, and two papers are being prepared for submission. Five PhD dissertations and three theses have been written. The developed software has been posted on the group website: https://research.franklin.uga.edu/fmri/brainpack. Also, Dr. Lazar and Dr. Park gave presentations at various conferences, meetings, and seminars. Four PhD students supported by this NSF grant presented their work at various meetings such as Joint Statistical Meetings, CRCNS meeting, and Georgia Statistics Day. In addition, fMRI data and analysis questions generated by this project were incorporated into the Statistics Capstone Class, a year-long requirement for senior undergraduate Statistics students.  This class provides students with the experience of working on a long project, with real-life data from actual clients that is then presented in oral and written contexts.  This is crucial training, particularly for students who plan to work as statisticians after graduation.
